Murderbot must also be American, and possibly a teenager because he also does the bare minimum possible when it comes to his job.

...all they had was Murderbot, who just wanted everyone to shut up and leave it alone so it could watch the entertainment feed all day..

Hehe! Oh, you!

Unfortunately for Murderbot, someone is trying to kill the humans that he's supposed to protect in between soap opera episodes. That sucks.

I've got four perfectly good humans here and I didn't want them to get killed...it would look bad on my record, and my record was already pretty terrible.

Priorities, you know. Permanent records are permanent.




So, Murderbot has to do some work, and he has to interact with humans - his two least favorite activities.




This story was short, but funny if you love depressed robots with low self-esteem.

Loved this book, it's a four point five and would've been a full five except for the ending.
For me, great scifi is when the author doesn't start out telling me how this new world works. I'm far more interested in how the characters act/behave/ survive in this world that is unfamiliar to me. Good scifi hits the ground running giving the reader enough credit to keep up as the author slowly metes out the world building while setting a very dynamic conflict.
My favorite scifi of late is Old Man's War, what a great read (along with the two followups). All systems Red is on this same level for me. The story starts off at a run and doesn't let up until the end. I loved it.
The minor problem for me is that in normal story arcs there are four sections, conflict, complication, crisis, and conclusion. This book has the crisis and the conclusion it runs so hot at such a frenetic pace the whole book feels like the crisis in the arc. Because of this the final crisis fizzles or pales to some of the wonderful earlier action scenes. This also happened for me in the book, Passages. The scene on train in that book made the ending feel like a fizzle. But oh, was that train scene something else.
Doesn't matter though, I picked all the other Martha Wells books. She can really write a strong female character that is viewed through the eyes of a murderbot.
David Putnam author of the Bruno Johnson series.

As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.
Its name is Murderbot.

Assigned to a group of scientists who are conducting studies on a hostile planet. No sooner have we met and loved Murderbot, than a creature attacks them.
The hostile that had just exploded up out of the ground had a really big mouth, so I felt I needed a really big gun.
Murderbot is sometimes good at its job, so it rescues its charges and goes on its way.

There's one thing about Murderbot though, all they had was Murderbot, who just wanted everyone to shut up and leave it alone so it could watch the entertainment feed all day.

For some reason, the universe is conspiring to keep Murderbot away from its TV shows. It's all it lives for. All it cares for, liked the imaginary people on the entertainment feed way more than I liked real ones, but you can‚Äôt have one without the other.

This is the samest same I have ever samed. It's a lot easier to deal with fictional characters. They're limited to the realm of your imagination and when you don't want to deal with them you just don't think about them. But some characters sneak past that barrier. They thrive beyond your escapism and latch themselves onto you like a barnacle. Some annoy you. Some fascinate you. Some turn you on. But most importantly, some are you.

I am Murderbot. Patron saint of all antisocial introverts everywhere who just want to be left alone. But Murderbot is too- special. It deserves friends. It deserves joy, freedom and all the things we're told to live for. Will it get them? I hope to find out.

As most people finally hopping onto this in 2025, I've came into the knowledge of this book because of the recently released Apple tv show.
Besides, Alexander Skarsg√•rd stars in it as the so called Murderbot, so, as you must have already figured out, reading this was an absolute MUST.

Thing is, and the trend that seems to be my reading life this year (sadly) that I don't think this was what I expected. At all. Again.

Bear with me.

We follow the story of Murderbot (as he privately calls himself), a cyborg who has gone rogue, hacking its governor module, as he serves as a SecUnit to a survey team of humans in an (apparently) unexplored planet.

As a SecUnit his main function is to provide security to the humans he's assigned to, but things go south when a series of anomalies start to happen to the team, forcing him to go beyond his usual task as security and facing him face to face with his biggest fear: to connect.

And that's it. That's the book's premise. Given that this is what we call a novella (it runs at 92 pages on my kindle), things happen very very fast. So fast that we have little to no time at all to adapt to this new world, or to get to know the rest of the characters a little bit better. Least say to connect to them or even care about them. The book jumps from one scene to another, with us readers thrown in the midst of the action almost as the get go.

All we get to know is Murderbot, and his quirkiness, his reffusal to basic human interactions, how little he cares about almost anything and anyone (or that¬¥s what he says) and his addiction to binge watch entertainment media, specially a tv show called Sanctuary Moon.

The bot is the absolute highlight of this story and the sole reason to keep on reading this series. He's funny just as much as he's awkward and completely unusual. I bet that some introverts will feel seen in his behavior.

As I stated above my problem with this book is the lack of depth, and that's on its length. It comprises in less than 100 pages what other stories take at least 350 pages to tell. Or even more. So, you see my problem here.
I would've loved to know a little more of this world or the side characters motivations, their personalities, beyond what we are told, but I guess it is what it is.

Overall, a very light scifi adventure who serves as introduction for an exciting series, or that¬¥s what I heard. And that's what I hope. Fingers crossed.

One more thing. Murderbot is sexless, so don't expect anything dirty or naughty happening between these pages. At all.

Q: Has there been any interest in turning All Systems Red into a movie or TV show?

A: No, there‚Äôs been no interest that I know of. I‚Äôm not sure what would work best, though a movie or TV show would have to have a lot of voiceover, since so much of the story is internal to the main character.

Q: If this did happen, who would you like to see play the main characters and why them?

A: I‚Äôm not sure who would play Murderbot. I was always kind of imagining Viola Davis [Suicide Squad] for Dr. Mensah. In the story, Murderbot‚Äôs favorite show, The Rise And Fall Of Sanctuary Moon, is meant to be a far future version of How To Get Away With Murder.

RATING BREAKDOWN

I enjoyed that the setting was so developed for a novella, and that it was well integrated into the narrative without any info-dumps! I could easily understand the political structure, where security units fit, the governing module, Peservation Society, the tech, the social rules, and medical capabilities just from following along with the plot. What is most gripping about the story is the juxtaposition of a character designed to protect humans who can't actually stand them. Murderbot is also completely untethered to its programming, and so wouldn't even have to continue protecting humans, but does so for mysterious reasons, and is only really interested in watching TV. I love speculative fiction that can give social commentary on the present, and so many of us can probably relate to Murderbot‚Äîcompelled to serve society, while kind of detesting fellow humans, and only actually being motivated to rot at home. What a weirdly contradictory mode of being. And yet, Murderbot is capable, heroic, and likable. The character is so gripping, I may just have to continue with the series. Even though I find the plot to be predictable and simplistic, and the emotional impact to be non-existent. I also don't like any of the other characters, who don't seem developed or to get arcs. As a reader who likes earnest stories, deep themes, and epic scope, a cozy sci-fi probably isn't going to be my cup of tea. But Murderbot is a complex and intriguing enough character that I could see myself coming back for future installments just to see what the character will do next.

This is a novella nominated for several awards and I know why.

In this story, a security robot breaks its own company protocol, freeing itself from any restraints, thus allowing its personality to unfold. Through the eyes of "Murderbot" (she's named herself that way), we experience what it is like to work with and for humans, that humans come in all forms (good and bad and everything in between), what the company creating these robots programs them to do (and what not) - and, ultimately, we learn how confusing and difficult it is to find oneself.

Murderbot doesn't like humans very much. But it isn't hatred - rather, confusion. Add to that that she is SHY! Yep, a security bot made to kill people (and other stuff) is actually shy and would rather watch TV. *lol*

The writing was fast-paced and engaging, every character lively and distinct (not always easy, especially not in short stories) and the unobtrusive humour was delightful.

I will definitely continue reading this series after the great ending to this and can't wait to know more about Murderbot's adventures and self-discovery that also teach us a lot about what it is to be "human".

It‚Äôs true that you really can love anything. Because I fell in love with a Murderbot.

In All Systems Red, the first volume of The Murderbot Diaries, Martha Wells has created an unforgettable character: that of Murderbot. A self-aware security android, Murderbot has recently hacked into its very own governor module in order to achieve a bit more autonomy. And while on its latest planetary mission ‚Äì a security detail in which the primary task is to protect a group of scientists ‚Äì both Murderbot and the scientific team are forced to examine what it means to be human.

Being a slim novella, Wells‚Äôs story is fast-paced and instantly entertaining. But though it may be short in length, it‚Äôs long on humor and human insight. Murderbot is quite funny and so very keen to point out the flaws and ineptitudes of the human race. I couldn‚Äôt get enough of its quips.

I listened to All Systems Red on audio, and Kevin Free‚Äôs narration is spot on. It‚Äôs a quick listen and ideal for anyone interested in trying out a little sci-fi.

And in case you‚Äôre wondering, you can bet I‚Äôll be listening to Book #2, Artificial Condition. More Murderbot is a must.

It is a great, interesting premise for a story, being quirky and engaging in the way it is told and the themes that it explore. Of course, All Systems Red is a novella, so it cannot explore too much in this first story, but for the page count, I would say that it is successful.

I would say that this is very good at creating a solid cast of characters, with the growth of the crew as well as Murderbot themselves working effectively alongside the plot and the threat that is present in this story. We have two concurrent dangers. If Murderbot is discovered to have this anxiety, they will be altered to be emotionless again, and alongside this the crew they are meant to be guarding and protecting is thrust into danger.

The characters are quirky, with this novella working well to balance the humour both in the dialogue and the internal monologue of our perspective, and then the tense moments that we experience as well.
